Message.Title: GOP has lost the popular vote in 5 of the last 6 elections
Message.Msg: and demographics dictate by 2016 the electorate will be 2-3% more democratic. The GOP may stupidly decide that they have to be more conservative (see footnote below cause there are those fools).* Or the GOP will step back from the baggers and move to the middle. Let's all hope we get the GOP back as a reasonable second party because they are on the course of extinction. ***“If we lose this election there is only one explanation – demographics,” Graham told Jonathan Martin of The Politico. “If I hear anybody say it was because Romney wasn’t conservative enough I’m going to go nuts. We’re not losing 95 percent of African-Americans and two-thirds of Hispanics and voters under 30 because we’re not being hard#$%$ enough.” “Nuts,” Senator? ”Hard #$%$?” Last time we checked Romney made it clear that he didn’t want to meaningfully reduce the size of the federal government because doing so would “cost jobs.” He also proposed to offset tax relief for middle income earners with tax hikes higher up the food chain. Additionally, he said there were parts of Obamacare that he liked and wanted leave in place. What on earth is “conservative” about those positions?

Message.Title: It's Over
Message.Msg: Romney has conceded, the election is over. The popular vote will come out close to even, but the Electoral College isn't close -- Obama has run an effective tactical campaign, and his ground game was very effective. Hurricane Sandy was the "November Surprise", and Chris Christie was the Republican's grand Judas. I was shocked by the Democratic turnout -- a lot of pollsters are vindicated. So I was wrong, and several liberals on this board are celebrating tonight. Enjoy it. This is a disaster for the nation, of course. A parade of horribles is now visible on the horizon -- it takes no imagination whatsoever to catalogue them. We are now a nation of "free stuff" voters. The consequences of this are waiting for us. I guess the practical man figures out how to navigate this, rather than sloppily complaining about the arbitrary feel of all this. Another serious recession is now guaranteed, as is chaos in the Middle East, and the packing of the Supreme Court with liberal hacks who don't even know what the Constitution says, or means. The scandals will now be buried and beyond investigation. History is written by the winners. The first phone call from Obama was to Clinton -- the King of the Charlatans passes the baton. It's a depressing narrative, and offers little hope. By 2016, we'll have 10% headline unemployment, underlying umemployment much higher, a $20 trillion deficit with no plan to address it, we will have had no budgets in any of these years, and the best case scenario will be a European postmodern fatalistic attitude about the way things are supposed to be. If somehow America has learned its lesson by 2016, it will be too late. This was the tipping point, and we missed it. Just watch. I wish I had better investing instincts about how to navigate this. I don't. At the moment, my kneejerk instinct is AUM (Assets Under Mattress), but with a President who will brutalize the dollar with no concern for its intrinsic value, even that will be ineffective. What we have to accept is that we have now breached the tipping point, and that that has consequences. Every great society has its denouement -- ours took a long time, but here it is. We have the outcome we deserve. Apres 2012, le deluge. (Darviris, that actually IS French -- evangelium was spouting Latin.)

Topic.Title: FOUR YEARS AHEAD OF LAMEDUCK0BAMA AND CONGRESS GRIDLOCK

Message.Msg: In the teabagger world the GOP won more seats in both the House and Senate. Screwed democrats are In the real world In the Senate, Democrats picked up at least one seat, and Republicans lost one — meaning the 2013 Senate will have at least 51 Democrats, at least 44 Republicans, and two independents. Three seats have yet to be decided. With 15 seats out of 435 still undecided, projections also indicate little will change in the House. Republicans currently have 233 seats, while Democrats so far have won 187. Republican Representative John Boehner of Ohio will likely retain his post as House Speaker.

Message.Msg: And Obama got about 10 million fewer votes than in 2008. A profound drop of support. Still, what he got was enough. What we saw last night was an overall drop in voter turnout than in 2008, the problem was that the (D)s were more organized than the (R)s. Now, if there had been no Sandy to distract from Romney's momentum, he would now be president. As I've said here before, Obama won on a hurricane. Did he remember to thank the 100 dead who gave him the election? Doubt it
